description: A major Romano-British religious complex on a promontory overlooking the River Severn. Coin evidence apparently suggests that the cult continued into the early 5th CE, even though the temple superstructure seems to have collapsed by 370 CE.
bibliography: Martyn, Blick, Brindle, et al, (2015), Lydney Park (Gloucestershire), available at: https://doi.org/10.5284/1030449
Smith, A., (2008), The Fate of Pagan Temples in South-East Britain, in Ritual Landsacpes of South-East Britain
Casey, Hoffmann, (1999), Excavations at the Roman temple at Lydney Park, Gloucestershire in 1980 and 1981, Antiquaries Journal, 79
Scott-Garrett, (1959), Roman Iron Mine in Lydney Park (1959), Trans Bristol and Gloucestershire Archaeological Society, 78
Richmond, I., (1955), in Roman Britain, pg. 139
Wheeler, R., Wheeler, T., (1932), Report on the excavation of the prehistoric, Roman and post-Roman site at Lydney Park, Gloucestershire (1932), Society of Antiquaries Rep, IX
Wheeler, R., (1932), Report on the Excavations ... in Lydney Park
Ward, J., (1911), Roman Era in Britain
Bathurst, W., King, C., (1879), Roman Antiquities at Lydney Park
